DataElement.preferredName: Treatment First Course Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Therapy Date
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Date of initiation of the first course therapy for the tumor being reported, using the SEER definition of first course.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Treatment First Course Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program Therapy
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Initiation of the first course therapy for the tumor being reported, using the SEER definition of first course.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.:Preceding all others in time or space or degree.:A period of protocol-prescribed activity or intervention.

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.
Preceding all others in time or space or degree.
Passage through time; duration; a systematic or/and orderly succession; a sequence, e.g. course of treatment; a mode of action or behavior; natural development, typical manner of proceeding.

Property.preferredName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program Therapy
Property.preferredDefinition: A cancer registry mandated under the National Cancer Act of 1971 to operate and maintain a population-based cancer reporting system, reporting periodically estimates of cancer incidence and mortality in the United States. The Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program is a continuing project of the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health. Among its goals, in addition to assembling and reporting cancer statistics, are the monitoring of annual cancer incident trends and the promoting of studies designed to identify factors amenable to cancer control interventions. (From a brochure of the National Cancer Institute, NIH Publication No. 91-3074, October 1990):An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.longName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program
Concepts.definition: A program of the National Cancer Institute that provides information on cancer statistics in an effort to reduce the cancer burden among the U.S. population.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

[Explanatory Comment: Enter 8 digit date when available; otherwise use one of the listed permissible values.]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.
